"Some of it is down to economic factors and some of it is down to a general lack of motivation. What has been missing here is for there to be a clear explanation for why these workers go out of work."

The large camera originally belonged to the pioneers of landscape and climbing photography, George and Ashley Abraham. The Lake District images are on display at Keswick Museum and Art Gallery until 12 May. Mr Iddon said: "With mobile phone cameras and Instagram, photography has become something very immediate, something that is easy to do with little thought. completed: Henry Iddon clambered up some of England 's highest mountains to capture images of the landscape and climbers using a Victorian glass plate camera . The large camera originally belonged to Henry 's grandfather ( and Iddon family photographer ) but he adapted it to take two by four inch glass plates . These glass plates produced images that were larger than that of a modern disposable camera and much heavier . Henry used to bring along at least one assistant in addition to himself and their equipment would normally weigh in excess of twenty kilos . The photographs of Iddon ' s were normally exposed to the light for around ten minutes and thus were not suitable for recording fast- moving action . Rather , Henry decided to record those magnificent aspects of the English countryside that have remained unchanged since he first made his exposures of the English fells . It was this desire to capture and record the true nature of the English fell system which first led Idd o to use large format

The Office of Road and Rail insists they are safe provided the right equipment and training is given. As well as walking out on strike, Merseyrail members will also not work any "rest days" from Monday 7 March indefinitely. RMT general secretary Mick Cash said the result "sends out the clearest possible message" that the union "is prepared to stand up and fight for public safety and the guard guarantee". Arriva Rail North, which operates Northern trains, provides services across the north of England.

North Weald in Essex was established in 1916 as an RAF base for fighter planes to combat airship raids over London. Fighter planes, mainly Hurricanes, were based there from 1916 to 1918. Two years later, British planes also dropped supplies to the French troops fighting the Germans in Africa. In 1917 British servicemen set up the first permanent police station, the Chichester Police Post. The base included a fire station, four air-raid shelters and a telephone exchange with a telephone operator who was able to switch to German on the first ring (this was one of a number of secret telegraph lines run under the table in the base). As part of the effort to counter German submarine activity off the coast of Britain, RAF Typhoons were also based at Weald in 1917. Weald also saw military aircraft being used for practice runs by the Royal Flying Corps.

"People who use social media at night are more likely to be depressed, more likely to seek the help of their medical profession, more likely to binge drink — and more likely to use illegal drugs," the researchers wrote in their findings.

The study is the first to show increased negative emotions in night users compared with those who wake up.

The findings indicate that not all night users experience increased negative emotions.

"This is very important because night activity is only one of many factors that contribute to negative emotions. In this study, the use of social media is one factor among many, and it is only one factor among other contributors," co-author Dr. Steven C. Davis, chairman and co-director of the Center on Health Disparities and Health Disparities Research, said in the statement.

The BBC at that time was the only national radio station and in order to provide more programming there were regional studios in Britain . However local studios in London did not broadcast on the weekends which saw the emergence of Independent Local Radio ( ILR ) , where the DJs had a great deal of freedom . The British Broadcasting Corporation ( BBC ) in London broadcast a mix of music from 195 4 that was called `` easy listening `` .
